qas.question: What Roman leader aspired to be a living god?
What form of government did Cesar seem to be attempting?
To what ruler did foreign allies offer a divine cult?
For what was Augustus's reformed system of government notiable?
By the end of Augustus's reign what was an established fact?

context: The first and last Roman known as a living divus was <a0_0>Julius Caesar<a0_0/>, who seems to have aspired to <a1_0>divine monarchy<a1_0/>; he was murdered soon after. Greek allies had their own traditional cults to rulers as divine benefactors, and offered similar cult to Caesar's successor, <a2_0>Augustus<a2_0/>, who accepted with the cautious proviso that expatriate Roman citizens refrain from such worship; it might prove fatal. By the end of his reign, Augustus had appropriated Rome's political apparatus – and most of its religious cults – within his "reformed" and thoroughly <a3_0>integrated<a3_0/> system of government. Towards the end of his life, he cautiously allowed cult to his numen. By then the <a4_0>Imperial cult<a4_0/> apparatus was fully developed, first in the Eastern Provinces, then in the West. Provincial Cult centres offered the amenities and opportunities of a major Roman town within a local context; bathhouses, shrines and temples to Roman and local deities, amphitheatres and festivals. In the early Imperial period, the promotion of local elites to Imperial priesthood gave them Roman citizenship.
